questions.q: Every computer or device on a network must have an IP address for what purpose?
questions.explanation: Devices need an IP address for communication purposes [1].

questions.q: What is a 'Static IP'?
questions.explanation: A static IP is where a user assigns a device an IP address manually [1].
options: An IP assigned automatically by a server
An IP assigned manually by a user
An IP that changes every hour

questions.q: True or False: Manual assignment was the original method used in the beginning of networking.
questions.explanation: Manual assignment (Static IP) was the original method used [1].

questions.q: What does DHCP stand for?
questions.explanation: DHCP stands for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol [2].

questions.q: What is the primary function of DHCP?
questions.explanation: DHCP enables automatic assignment of IP addresses and other configuration settings [2].
options: To automatically assign IP addresses and network settings
To translate private IPs to public IPs

questions.q: The DHCP process is explained using which acronym?
questions.explanation: The process of DHCP is explained using the acronym DORA [2].

questions.q: In the DORA process, what does the 'D' stand for?
questions.explanation: The first step is the Discover phase [2].

questions.q: During the 'Discover' phase, the client sends what type of message?
questions.explanation: The client broadcasts a Discover message to find a server [3].

questions.q: In the DORA process, what does the 'O' stand for?
questions.explanation: The second step is the Offer phase [2, 3].

questions.q: In the DORA process, what does the 'R' stand for?
questions.explanation: The third step is the Request phase [2, 3].

questions.q: In the DORA process, what does the 'A' stand for?
questions.explanation: The final step is the Acknowledgment message [2, 3].

questions.q: What is a 'DHCP Scope'?
questions.explanation: DHCP Scope defines the range (From-To) of IP addresses to be assigned [4].
options: The hardware model of the DHCP server
The range of IP addresses the server is allowed to assign
The time it takes to assign an IP
The list of blocked IP addresses

questions.q: What is an IP 'Lease'?
questions.explanation: A lease is the amount of time an IP address is assigned to a computer [5].
options: The cost of the IP address
The amount of time an IP is assigned to a computer
The distance the IP signal travels
A permanent assignment of an IP

questions.q: What is a primary reason for using IP leases?
questions.explanation: Leases help make sure the DHCP server does not run out of IPs in its scope [5].
options: To ensure the server does not run out of IP addresses
To hide the device from the internet

questions.q: What does NAT stand for?
questions.explanation: NAT stands for Network Address Translation [6].

questions.q: Which type of NAT maps an unregistered (Private) IP to a registered (Public) IP on a 1:1 basis?
questions.explanation: Static NAT maps a Private IP to a Public IP on a one-to-one basis [6].

questions.q: Static NAT is particularly useful for which type of devices?
questions.explanation: It is useful for hosts that must have a consistent address accessible from the Internet [6].
options: Web servers or hosts accessible from the Internet

questions.q: How does Dynamic NAT assign public addresses?
questions.explanation: Dynamic NAT uses a pool of public addresses and assigns them first-come, first-served [6].
options: Using a pool on a first-come, first-served basis
Based on the device's MAC address

questions.q: What does PAT stand for?
questions.explanation: PAT stands for Port Address Translation [7].

questions.q: What is another common name for PAT?
questions.explanation: PAT is sometimes called NAT overload [7].

questions.q: How does PAT allow multiple private IPs to use a single public IP?
questions.explanation: PAT maps multiple private addresses to a single public IP by using different ports [7].

questions.q: Which device typically performs PAT?
questions.explanation: This is what most home broadband routers do [7].

questions.q: How does PAT add a degree of security to a session?
questions.explanation: It validates that incoming packets were requested, adding security [7].
options: By validating that incoming packets were requested
By changing the IP every minute

questions.q: What does APIPA stand for?
questions.explanation: APIPA stands for Automatic Private IP Addressing [8].

questions.q: When does a computer use APIPA?
questions.explanation: APIPA occurs if the computer can't reach the DHCP server [8].
options: When it connects to a web server
When it cannot reach a DHCP server
When it has a static IP
When the internet is too fast

questions.q: What is the specific IP address range used by APIPA?
questions.explanation: APIPA assigns an address in the 169.254.0.1 to 169.254.255.254 range [9].

questions.q: True or False: Computers with APIPA addresses can communicate with devices outside their own subnet.
questions.explanation: They can only communicate with each other on the same subnet [9].

questions.q: What happens if a computer using APIPA later detects a DHCP server?
questions.explanation: The computer will replace the self-assigned address with the one from the DHCP server [9].
options: It replaces the APIPA address with the DHCP address

questions.q: What does VPN stand for?
questions.explanation: VPN stands for Virtual Private Network [9].

questions.q: What is the primary function of a VPN?
questions.explanation: A VPN establishes a secure and reliable connection over an unsecured network [9].
options: To establish a secure network connection over an unsecured network
To increase the number of ports on a router
To replace the need for an ISP

questions.q: Essay: Briefly explain the DORA process in DHCP.
questions.explanation: Source: [2, 3]
questions.answer: DORA consists of Discover (client broadcasts to find server), Offer (server suggests IP), Request (client asks for IP), and Acknowledge (server confirms assignment).

questions.q: Essay: Describe the difference between Static NAT and Dynamic NAT.
questions.explanation: Source: [6]
questions.answer: Static NAT uses a 1:1 permanent mapping between a private and public IP, while Dynamic NAT uses a pool of public IPs assigned on a first-come, first-served basis.

questions.q: True or False: DHCP can assign other network settings besides the IP address.
questions.explanation: DHCP enables assignment of IP addresses and other network configuration settings [2].

questions.q: True or False: In PAT, the router uses source port numbers to distinguish between different client sessions.
questions.explanation: PAT uses unique source port numbers to distinguish between translations [7].

questions.q: In Dynamic NAT, what happens when there are more hosts than available public IP addresses in the pool?
questions.explanation: It chooses an address not already in use; it is useful when fewer addresses are available than hosts [6].
options: Hosts must wait until an IP is not in use by another host
It automatically switches to Static NAT

questions.q: How often does a computer with an APIPA address check for a DHCP server?
questions.explanation: Every few minutes the computers will check to see if they can contact a DHCP server [9].

questions.q: True or False: An IP lease could be set for one day.
questions.explanation: For example, the lease could be for one day [5].

questions.q: Which type of NAT is best for a home with multiple devices and only one ISP-provided public IP?
questions.explanation: PAT maps multiple private IPs to a single public IP, which is what home routers do [7].

questions.q: The term 'Inside Global IP address' is associated with which protocol?
questions.explanation: PAT uses unique source port numbers on the inside global IP address [7].

questions.q: Essay: Why is the DHCP lease mechanism important for network management?
questions.explanation: Source: [5]
questions.answer: It prevents the server from running out of addresses by reclaiming IPs that are no longer in use after the lease time expires.
